awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Theoretical and Experimental Investigation of Synthetic Micro/Nano-Swimmers in Shear-thinning Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
Synthetic swimmers are engineered microscopic or nanoscopic objects that mimic how natural microorganisms swim through their environment.  Synthetic swimmers that can move through biological fluids show great promise in biomedical applications such as drug delivery and microsurgery.  Successful applications of these swimmers to biomedical tasks rely on their ability to move through biological fluids, such as blood, with complex and varying properties that respond to their surroundings. While there have been recent studies on the subject of locomotion in these fluids, much remains to be learned about the influence of directional applied forces or other motions such shaking and agitation, on swimming.  This research project aims to quantify and elucidate the impacts of complex (non-Newtonian) fluid properties on the locomotion of synthetic micro-swimmers. The outcomes will enable the development of micro-robots with robust swimming capabilities for next generation healthcare applications.  The project will integrate research and education through senior design projects and undergraduate research participation. By leveraging existing university programs with new activities derived from the research project, the researchers will provide outreach to approximately 120 high-school students annually.  The project will also support an exhibition entitled "Swallowing a Surgeon" at the California Science Center (Los Angeles, CA) in order to expose the general public to the challenges and progress made towards designing biomedical micro-robots.

In this collaborative research project between Santa Clara University and the California Institute of Technology, computations and experiments will be used to understand locomotion in shear-thinning fluids and to identify effective strategies to account for this non-Newtonian fluid behavior in the design of synthetic swimmers. Existing propulsion mechanisms can be broadly categorized into chemically-powered swimmers that harvest energy from local chemical reactions, and swimmers that require external fields for actuation. In this research project, representative model systems from each category will be studied to evaluate the impacts of shear-thinning rheology on major types of synthetic swimmers at small scales. Theory and experiments will use catalytic motors and flexible magnetic nanowire propellers to provide a comprehensive understanding of how distinct types of non-Newtonian fluid behaviors and their interactions affect locomotion at small scales. The completion of this project will lead to new fundamental knowledge on fluid-structure interactions and phoretic motion in complex fluids. This improved understanding will in turn guide the design of next-generation synthetic swimmers that can move through biological fluids effectively.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SANTA CLARA COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Background: Synthetic micro/nano-robots that swim like microorganisms hold great promise for biomedical applications. However, unlike simple Newtonian fluids, these micro/nano-swimmers must navigate biological fluids such as blood and mucus, which exhibit complex properties including shear-thinning rheology and viscoelasticity. This collaborative project between Santa Clara University (led by PI On Shun Pak) and the California Institute of Technology (led by PI Wei Gao) integrates theoretical and experimental investigations to advance our fundamental understanding of microscopic locomotion in complex fluids. The new knowledge and insights provide guidance for the design of synthetic microswimmers for biomedical applications, including targeted drug delivery and microsurgery.

Intellectual Merit: Theoretical and computational models were developed to uncover how different behaviors of complex (non-Newtonian) fluids affect the performance of microswimmers employing various propulsion mechanisms, including acoustic, magnetic, elastohydrodynamic, and chemically-powered phoretic propulsion. The findings provided guidance for designing and optimizing microswimmer propulsion in shear-thinning fluids and other complex fluid environments. In addition, machine learning techniques were explored to design the locomotory gaits of model microswimmers and enable them to adaptively navigate dynamically changing complex environments. The collaborative research also combined simulations and experiments to develop a new class of bioresorbable microswimmers with robust propulsion performance across diverse biological fluids, including urine, gastrointestinal fluid, wound fluid, and whole blood. In vitro and in vivo experimental evidence demonstrated the promising capabilities of these new microswimmers in tumor treatment. These findings were published in leading journals in fluid dynamics and soft matter physics, as well as high-impact multidisciplinary journals, underscoring their intellectual and scientific significance.

Broader Impacts: The partnership between Santa Clara University, a primarily undergraduate institution, and Caltech, a research-intensive institution, fostered synergistic collaboration and communication across different types of institutions within the U.S. higher education system. Undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers in both institutions were actively involved in the research. The findings were widely disseminated through journal publications and conference presentations, as well as outreach efforts aimed at high school students, inspiring the next generation of STEM workforce. Media coverage of the research findings also helped enhance public awareness and appreciation of science and technology.

This project has enhanced the understanding of microscopic locomotion in non-Newtonian fluids, providing key insights for developing synthetic microswimmers capable of navigating complex biological environments. The outcomes mark a significant step toward unlocking the transformative potential of microswimmers for biomedical applications.


Last Modified: 02/19/2025
Modified by: On Shun Pak
